items.title: Punch-Marked Coins — Earliest Silver Currency
notes: These coins were created by cutting a silver sheet to standard weight and punching it with symbols using separate punches.
Different regions used specific symbols such as sun, tree-in-railing, bull, elephant, etc.
Represent the first organized monetary system in India.

items.title: Magadha Series Punch-Marked Coins
notes: Features symbols unique to the Magadha kingdom.
Magadha became the dominant state during the time of the Mahajanapadas and Mauryan Empire.

items.title: Gandhara Series Punch-Marked Coins
notes: Shows distinctive motifs such as the humped bull, elephant, and geometric punches.
Linked to early trade routes connecting India with Persia and Central Asia.

items.title: Mauryan Standardized Punch-Marked Coins
notes: Under the Mauryan empire, punch-marked coins became fully standardized.
Official royal symbols were included to ensure authenticity and state authority.

items.title: Tribal Janapada Coins
notes: Issued by smaller tribal republics or janapadas.
Designs were less standardized and often depict tribal symbols.

items.title: Bent-Bar Silver Coins
notes: Long rectangular silver bars bent slightly in the middle.
Introduced through trade with Greek kingdoms and later localized.

items.title: Early Symbolic Copper Coins
notes: These coins used symbols like animals and plants to indicate issuing authorities or cities.
Copper was used for smaller, local transactions.

items.title: Indo-Greek Coins
notes: Feature bilingual inscriptions in Greek and Brahmi scripts.
Common designs include Greek deities, rulers' portraits, and elephants.

items.title: Satavahana Early Copper Coins
notes: Depicts symbols like the 'Ujjain symbol' and elephants.
Used for local and regional commerce in southern India.
